channel.title: The Complete List of Cybersecurity Terms and Their Definitions on Tech Terminologies
channel.description: Recent content in The Complete List of Cybersecurity Terms and Their Definitions on Tech Terminologies

item.title: What is a PIN (Personal Identification Number)?
item.description: A Personal Identification Number, or PIN, is a numerical code used to authenticate a user’s identity and protect against unauthorized access.

item.title: What is MFA (Multi-Factor Authentication)?
item.description: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is a security process that requires users to provide multiple pieces of evidence (or “factors”) to verify their identity before they can access a system or perform a task.

item.title: What is Cloud Security Control?
item.description: Cloud security controls refer to the measures that organizations put in place to ensure the security and integrity of their data and systems when using cloud computing services.

item.title: What is Data in Use?
item.description: Data in use refers to data that is actively being accessed and processed by a computer or device for a specific purpose.

item.title: What is Shift Left Testing?
item.description: Shift left testing is a software testing approach that involves shifting testing activities to earlier stages of the software development process.

item.title: What is Digital Forensics?
item.description: Digital forensics is the practice of identifying, preserving, analyzing, and presenting digital evidence in a manner that is legally admissible.

item.title: What is E2EE (End-to-end encryption)?
item.description: End-to-end encryption (E2EE) is a method of transmitting data where only the sender and the intended recipient can read the messages.

item.title: What is APT (Advanced Persistent Threat)?
item.description: An Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) is a type of cyberattack that is typically launched by a nation-state or other highly organized and funded group.

item.title: What is CEH (Certified Ethical Hacker)?
item.description: A Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH) is a professional who understands and knows how to find vulnerabilities and weaknesses in target systems and uses the same knowledge and tools as a malicious hacker, but instead using their skills and knowledge in a lawful and ethical manner to assess the security of target systems.

item.title: What is a Malicious Software?
item.description: Malicious software, also known as malware, is a type of software that is specifically designed to cause harm to a computer system.

item.title: What is a Malware?
item.description: Malware is a term used to describe any software that is specifically designed to harm or exploit a computer system.

item.title: What is a Trojan (Trojan Horse)?
item.description: A Trojan horse, or Trojan, is a type of malicious software that is designed to deceive users into believing it is legitimate while actually performing undesirable or harmful actions on their systems.

item.title: What is Document Grinding?
item.description: Document grinding, also known as document shredding or document destruction, is the process of securely destroying physical documents to protect sensitive information from being accessed by unauthorized parties.

item.title: What is a Keylogger?
item.description: A keylogger, also known as a keystroke logger or keyboard logger, is a type of software or hardware that tracks and records every keystroke made on a computer’s keyboard.

item.title: What is a Cybersquatter?
item.description: A cybersquatter is an individual or organization that registers, traffics in, or uses a domain name in bad faith with the intent to benefit from the reputation of another person’s trademark.

item.title: What is Cyberbullying?
item.description: Cyberbullying is the use of technology to harass, threaten, or intimidate someone, often repeatedly.

item.title: What is Adware?
item.description: Adware, short for “advertising-supported software,” is a type of software that displays advertisements on a computer or mobile device.

item.title: What is NBA (Network Behavior Analysis)?
item.description: Network behavior analysis is a cybersecurity technique that involves the continuous monitoring and analysis of network traffic and activity to identify unusual or malicious behavior.

item.title: What is User Identification?
item.description: User identification is the process of identifying and authenticating a user’s identity in order to grant them access to a system or service.

item.title: What is DAC (Discretionary Access Control)?
item.description: Discretionary Access Control (DAC) is a type of access control that is based on the idea that an individual user or process has the discretion to grant or revoke access to resources that they own or control.

item.title: What is Social Engineering?
item.description: Social engineering is a term used to describe the psychological manipulation of individuals into performing actions or divulging sensitive information.

item.title: What is a Product Key?
item.description: A product key, also known as a license key or activation key, is a unique alphanumeric code that is required to install and activate a software application.

item.title: What is a License Key?
item.description: A license key, also known as a product key, is a unique code that is used to activate a software program.

item.title: What is a Serial Number?
item.description: A serial number is a unique identification number or code that is used to activate a software application.

item.title: What is a Digital Signature?
item.description: A digital signature is a form of electronic signature that uses a combination of cryptography and authentication to provide a secure way of verifying the identity of the sender of an electronic document and the integrity of the document itself.

item.title: What is an Activation Key?
item.description: An activation key, also known as a serial number or license key, is a unique code that is used to register or activate a software application.

item.title: What is ACL (Access Control List)?
item.description: An access control list (ACL) is a list of permissions that are associated with a particular resource, such as a file, folder, or network device.
